item.title: Health, Marriage, and Labour Market Success
item.description: Introduction 1 Literature Review 1.1 Human Capital Theory 1.2 The Influence of Marriage on Health 2 Econometric specification 3 Estimation Method 4 Results Conclusion References Introduction To what extent does the labor income decrease if a person was diagnosed with a serious illness? Are the incomes of married individuals less affected than those of unmarried individuals? In order to answer these questions, I will first review the literature on human capital theory with particular attention to the assumed positive effect of schooling, professional training, and health on the labor income of individuals.

item.title: Academic Writing with RMarkdown
item.description: Introduction Have you ever thought about conducting statistical analysis and writing the results in the same software? This article explains why this is useful and how it works. RMarkdown merges narrative text with embedded chunks of R-code and creates an elegantly formatted document, including data plots and publication-quality tables. There is no need anymore for Word and other text editors. Arguably, there are many comprehensive and intelligible guides for writing RMarkdown documents on the internet.

item.title: Path Dependencies in Careers of Visual Artists
item.description: 1 Introduction 2 Concept 3 Data 4 Path dependencies 5 Conclusion 1 Introduction This article analyzes how social hierarchies between visual artists arise and persist. Specifically, I draw on an empirical strategy proposed by Fraiberger et al. (2018) to distinguish successful and less successful careers. The authors analyze artist careers as sequences of exhibition participations in museums and galleries of higher or lower prestige.

item.title: Economic Origins and Outcomes of the Arab Spring
item.description: 1 The Revolution Constraint 2 Evidence from the Arab Spring 2.1 The case of Egypt 2.2 A comparative perspective 3 Conclusion The term Arab Spring denotes a variety of regime protests, uprisings and armed rebellions, which differ from each other in several respects. On the one hand, they differ in their extent, ranging from local to nationwide activities, and on the other hand in the achievement of different results: from minor state concessions to appease the population, to stronger reactions in which the government was overthrown.
